reviewText: I love jazz but generally avoid "fusion" efforts and performances involving electric instruments. (I love electric/electronic instruments, just not in jazz.) Pat Metheny's work is an exception for me. His work is pretty consistently interesting, tasteful, and musically sophisticated. Obviously, to some extent, one's enjoyment of this video will turn on how one likes "The Way Up" as music. But, the lovely thing about this video is a straightforward presentation of this group of amazing musicians presenting this rather complicated piece in concert. There are few distracting camera or editing tricks. Just a very competent and skillful job of documenting this performance. Almost all of the musicians play multiple instruments in this performance, and it's fascinating to watch the musicians move from instrument-to-instrument.
summary: Master musicians at work, beautifully documented.

reviewText: i don't even understand how these men remember everything that's asked of each of them over this approximately 70 minute song . that they all play with such incredible prowess and beauty is truly stunning . a gift for the eyes , ears and mind . not many people on earth can compose something this ambitious . to also have the ability to play the composition in front of live audiences is truly nothing short of amazing . much thanks to each and every one of these remarkable musicians and the KOREAN crew who documented the event . must see modern creative jazz for anyone seeking that experience . thrilling .

reviewText: Pat Metheny and Lyle Mays have collaborated on memorable studio sessions and the Pat Metheny Group continues to create magical moments in concert.In what was the most musically demanding concept in their careers, Metheny and Mays crafted a technical masterpiece with definite classical overtones, The Way Up. The CD earned The Pat Metheny Group its 10th Grammy Award and Metheny his 17th prestigious prize.And for about the cost of the CD, the complete performance of the piece is shown from a 2005 concert in Seoul, South Korea. This is 70 minutes of the most impressive textural music that surprisingly sounds better live than in the studio.Since exploding onto the jazz scene, Metheny has been a very accessible to the media. The bonus 22-minute interview with him is highly informative and provides a very unique perspective on the music.The Way Up - Live captures a special evening in a legendary career that continues to strive for and reach new artistic heights.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I wasn't aware this dvd was out, and when I saw that it was out, i ordered it right away. If your a fan of the way up, i highly recommend this dvd. The DTS surround on this dvd is amazing, i almost perfer these concert dvds over actually being there in concert because you get to hear everything. You can tell they spent alot of time working out the surround tracks. Pats tone is phenominal (like always), and the rest of the band is just kickin! Amazing solos throughout the hole dvd! DEFINATELY IN MY TOP 10 concert DVDS

reviewText: This is the first and only Blu-Ray disc I have bought so far.Picture quality: 5/5. Very good. It's almost like having the musicians in the room with you.Sound quality: I can't comment on this, as I haven't connected it to my 5.1 system yet. Played through my Sony TV, the sound is at least OK!Content: 3/5. This is where this disc disappoints. It's great to see Metheny on Blu-Ray, but such a shame that the recording should be of one of his worst-ever compositions. Metheny will be remembered as one of the greatest composers of the last quarter of the 20th century, so posterity deserves a good record of concert performances of his greatest pieces.Those of us who saw the PMG perform 'The Way Up' will recall that after completing the marathon piece, the band then played many of their greatest hits -- almost as if it were a farewell tour. It is a great pity that this disc does not record a complete gig -- just the first half.Most of the close-up shots are well chosen. I just didn't need to see the podgy, half-committed Steve Rodby reading the music that the rest of the band had bothered to memorise. Bring back Richard Bona, a far better bassist!If ever the PMG go on tour again, you can bet that 'The Way Up' will be reduced to a 10-minute summary (if that). It is a terrible epitaph for a fantastic group.

reviewText: this was the first music HDDVD I purchased, after owning hundreds of Music and concert DVDS over the past 10 years. Fantatsic clear picture. I assume thats the only difference between this and the DVD release. The sound is great like every other DVD I have of Pat's. If you own an HDDVD or Blu Ray player then you own it to yourself to buy this for one of those formats as the price on all three formats is similar. That being said if it was 10 dollars more I don't know if the difference in resolution is worth 10 bucks, 480P sure looks fine still, I'm starting to think this whole upgraded format war is overblown. For 5 bucks maybe worth it 10 no. Of course This latest concert is all his new material which was very enjoyable. Its a great HDDVD overall, not much extra content or special HDDVD stuff but thats not why you buy a Pat Metheny disc is it? Summing it up, great picture in HD, great 5.1 sound, New material played as it was meant to be heard as an album. If you love Pat you will love this. Ohh and par for the course great line up for his band.

reviewText: When he emerged on the scene three decades ago, Pat Metheny was already a great and innovative jazz composer and guitarist.  Since then, he has only improved, and with this performance we encounter an artist possessing a sublime mastery of his craft.  And of course we shouldn't forget that this is the Pat Metheny Group, not a solo act, and Pat's collaborators are indeed all superb in their own right (Antonio Sanchez especially captivates me).I found the music itself to be simply breathtaking and transporting.  Like a work of classical music, this piece runs continuously for just over an hour, so it's demanding for both the artists and the audience, but we all benefit from rising to the challenge.  Of course the music has jazz roots and elements, but with that distinctive Pat Metheny feel (joyous, but with a tinge of some sort of sadness?).  The composition is often complex, but always in a measured way serving to enable richness of artistic expression, not complex for its own sake.  And the synergy among the band (and with the Korean audience) is perfect, with solos that take their moment to shine while still fitting seamlessly into the gestalt whole.Also be sure to watch the interview with Pat Metheny.  He speaks eloquently from his heart and mind, and in the process he conveys much profound insight and wisdom.  He also provides excellent context on how this piece was conceived, composed, and performed.  As a musician myself (guitar and drums), I gained a lot from his thoughts on the artist's journey.Finally, rest assured that the sound quality and camera work on this DVD are both excellent.Very highly recommended to Pat Metheny fans and to all other lovers of sophisticated (in the best sense) contemporary music.

reviewText: The Performance, Video and Audio are as good as it gets! This guy has been around since I can remember, early 70's, and has only gotten more creative and better as time goes by. His band is also of equal performances and creativity,(is that a trumpet making that sound?). The performances are spectacular, equal to Jeff Becks, although a totally different style. This Disc just goes to show how really good Blu-ray and it's newer audio formats are. The DTS Master Audio really shines on this disc, about the only thing you don't hear is their breathing. Wow what a recording!  If you want to show off your A/V system, or just enjoy a nice jazz disc, this is one heck of a good start!! (Or continuation if you have already started) Keep'um comming!!!!I wish Amazon had a 3 Criteria rating that would make for a quicker and more accurate and fair rating of Cd's, DVD's and Blu-ray's.1. Performance2. Quality of Audio3. Quality of Video (for DVD's and Blu-ray's)1.*****2.*****3.*****Bands that wish to have there performances recorded and recognised should be held to a standard. Poor audio, no matter how good the performance, is still a bad product. Those who would still purchase sub-standard audio quality recordings and rank that product highly are not doing the industry or the band justice. Demand better and we will get it, settle for less and that's what you'll get.

reviewText: This is a relatively short (68 min.) concert film shot in front of a stoic South Korean audience.  The music is essentially a one piece symphony of sorts, performed in 4 parts.  There are no real songs, just 7 talented musicians playing multiple instruments in an original concept of Metheny and his co-writer, keyboardist Lyle Mays.  It is beautiful to watch them perform and the resulting music is glorious to listen to.
summary: Short but sweet conceptual jazz concert
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I got the CD for this I couldn't think of how they could possibly pull this off live.  Then I went to the concert at the Beacon and was blown away how they not only performed it, but embellished upon it.This recording captures that accomplishment faithfully.  The symbosis with this, possibly the best line up the group has ever had, is palpable.It was true to the Pat Metheny Group concert experience. By that I mean that there is an intimacy to the group's music that even in a large auditorium, holds firm.  You are drawn in and are along for the ride whether it be the 68 minutes or the typical 2.5 hours of the average PMG concert.Everyone has their moments on this recording, everyone shines within the context of this piece, which while a perfect vehicle for improvisation never loses it's melodicism.  Everyone plays in context.It would've been nice if they would've also included some of the other pieces which were part of the tour, that were revisited after a long absence from the group's repertoire.I guess you can't have everything but I am satisfied with this DVD and the beauty and vision it contains.
summary: Amazing to see this done live.  A masterpiece!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a Metheny fan for many years, I wanted to really love this album.  The first three times I heard it, as well as the fourth time (live), I did love it.  Especially live.However, it was a short love affair because although this CD breaks new ground, and is dynamic and interesting, it feels ultimately more intelectual than emotional.  It is less lyrical and flowing than other Metheny work, so if you like a more abstract and provocative style, you will like this a lot, and I think many do.  For me, I find the abstract intelectual stuff more accesible if it is within a context that is still harmonic and beautiful and where the tune finds "resolution".  The famous "it don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing" for me means, it still has to be beautiful and moving to be enjoyable in the long run.In short, you will enjoy this a lot if you like provocotive cutting edge jazz/fusion.  Just don't expect this to be like previous Metheny Albums which are much more positive, flowing, tuneful, and emotionally moving.

reviewText: [The following review is written with the "general" listener in mind.  The Metheny fan (understandably there are legions) already knows that this is an indispensable item.]This is "contemporary jazz" on steroids, as Metheny and Mays have produced a kind of visual music that sweeps the listener along like a John Williams movie score.  It makes perfect sense, therefore, to go for the DVD over the CD.  In fact, the shot selection and editing are so tightly coordinated with the music, it's as though the cinematographer is an integral part of the production, as crucial to the whole as one of the musicians.  (Actually, he is--the bass player.  Wagner would call such an integration of music and drama a true "gesamstwerk."  The Russian filmmaking genius, Sergei Eisenstein, achieved a similar integration in his film "Alexander Nevsky" with the music of Prokofiev.  Perhaps the best integration of music and film yet is Trueba's "Calle 54," which showcases Cuban and Brazilian musicians playing the Steinway as you've never experienced it before.)There's also a surprising amount of solo space--not much inventive or thoughtful improvisation, perhaps, but at least plenty of room for each musician to display monster chops on limited scale patterns.  There are even some "walking-bass" sections in 4/4, providing rhythmic variety and an acknowledgement, at least, of the mainstream jazz tradition (though perhaps not enough to satisfy Django or Wes purists).  At times the melodic lead of unison guitar, electronically enhanced piano, and harmonica synthesizer becomes repetitious (at least for someone raised on Ellingtonian textures) as do the heavy accents on the first beats of measures, but overall "The Way Up" holds the listener's attention, creating the sense of a crescendoing, ebbing and surging, rising and falling vortex that exerts a compelling Promethean pull.Throughout, Metheny plays his audience like another instrument, bringing them to predictable applause with each loud climax, then backing way off on dynamics, tempo, and texture before initiating another orgasmic build-up of mounting flame and heat, kicking in the foreplay with minimalist, Steve Reich-like pulsations underlying the atemporal sonic colors, each accentuated by ride-cymbal sprays.  Soon the pulsations take the foreground while the melodic fragments are elongated and intensified through echoplex and doubling devices.  Again, the climax is signaled by the band's cadence and moment of silence, during which the crowd cheers again, appreciative of yet another orgiastic completion.As a piano player who has been known to stay up all night studying a manual simply to "split" a keyboard effectively (at least these guys can afford to hire a bass player) or program three pedals to trigger as many keyboards, I can also appreciate the "extra-musical" talents, techniques, and patience required to harness the technology (let alone make it work in public performance as it did off-stage).Finally, for a price comparable if not less expensive than the CD, how can you pass this one up?  (Perhaps this is the industry's response to the file downloading that's replacing CD's.  Soon we'll all be hooked on music DVD's, and a musician hopeful is going to have to "look good" for the cameras, possibly even enroll at Juilliard, The Actor's Studio, and NYU Filmmaking School at the same time.)
